awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Data Science and the Political Economy of International Security
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE). It has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. Across the globe, the United States faces a growing set of rapidly evolving, dauntingly complex political challenges. Economic issues sit at the root of both great power conflicts. These challenges are unfolding in a historically novel context. Against this backdrop, participants in this REU will conduct research on the connections between economics and international security, including both the economic incentives for military coercion and war and the coercive uses of economic statecraft. Equipping future scholars to both understand the economic dynamics that drive conflict and propose solutions is critical for pursuing US national interest in an era of economic interdependence. The Security and Political Economy (SPEC) Lab and the School of International Relations at the University of Southern California (USC) will provide ten undergraduates per year with an 8-week summer research experience (SRE), where they will engage in graduate-level research on the political economy of security and attend weekly workshops in research design, data science, and professional development. The program will develop a new generation of leaders who are diverse in their backgrounds and at the cutting edge in their social science skillsets.

The interrelated research projects we will undertake as part of the REU sit at the cutting edge of an emerging academic subfield, the political economy of security. Our two major data projects, the Global Military Activity Dataset and the Complex Economic Interdependence Data provide essential new measures of coercive bargaining over economic issues, allowing us to measure, in a fine-grained, disaggregated way, both the economic and military interactions between states. A comprehensive dataset of military exercises, patrols, and crisis mobilizations, allows us to identify the types of military activity that signal costly preparation for conflict, and to understand the process of coercive bargaining that often occurs without shots actually being fired. Similarly, by precisely measuring the nature of economic interdependence, we can then evaluate the conditions under which interdependence provides both power and vulnerability in coercive bargaining between states. Economic interdependence raises the costs of large-scale wars but may, paradoxically, make small-scale military conflicts more common. Some of these smaller-scale military conflicts are driven by issues related to the distribution of natural resources. As they work on these projects, SRE students are thus at the cutting edge of policy-relevant social science, using advanced data science techniques to grapple with some of the most pressing questions facing humanity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Economic issues sit at the root of both great power conflicts between the U.S. and China and Russia and regional disputes throughout Africa and the Middle East. Equipping future scholars to both understand the economic dynamics that drive conflict and propose solutions is critical for pursuing US national interest in an era of economic interdependence. From summer 2020 to 2022, the NSF REU program “Data Science and the Political Economy of International Security,” hosted by co-PIs Megan Becker and Benjamin Graham of the Security and Political Economy (SPEC) Lab at the University of Southern California, provided ten undergraduates per year with an 8-week summer research experience, where they engaged in graduate-level research on the political economy of security. The program supports the diversification of the academy by recruiting students from groups that are underrepresented in the professoriate and giving them the tools they need to succeed as researchers. Participants attended professional development programming focused on encouraging them to consider graduate school and other research-intensive careers in the social sciences.

Students worked on projects on a broad range of topics such as: how states use economic tools of coercion in their foreign policy, how economic dependence on natural resource wealth can fuel civil war, and how states and NGOs can cooperate to provide public education in conflict zones. They gathered data, synthesized literature, ran statistical analyses, and created public outreach materials.  

In addition to participating in faculty-mentored research projects, students attended weekly training workshops in research design and data science. A core part of the training curriculum that was provided to our REU participants was a series of training modules on applied data science using R. The modules focus on data management and data visualization for social science. When we had to transition the REU unexpectedly to a remote format in 2020, we invested in developing a version of these training modules that included short lecture videos posted to YouTube, along with PDF walkthroughs, groupwork assignments, and homework assignments. As REU students passed through these trainings, we also engaged them as instructors, developing revised and improved versions of the materials. Most notably, several REU students narrated the lecture videos in different training modules, and these videos have been viewed hundreds (in some cases thousands) of times each, reaching students well beyond our program. Our data curriculum is available to the public here: https://www.uscspec.org/applied-data-science-trainings
